title: Simplify
text: First, we need to use the Distributive Property to get rid of the parentheses, and then combine like terms.
speech: First, we need to use the Distributive Property to get rid of the parentheses, and then combine like terms.

title: Simplified Inequality
speech: The simplified inequality is  2 h plus 4, is less than or equal to, 7 h minus 11 .

title: Isolate
text: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
speech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.
pacedSpeech: We want to isolate the variable on one side of the inequality.

title: Subtraction Property of Inequality
text: To isolate the variable, we can subtract $$7h$$ and $$4$$ from both sides of the inequality. This gives us $$2h+4-7h-4 \leq 7h-11-7h-4$$.
speech: To isolate the variable, we can subtract  7 h  and  4  from both sides of the inequality. This gives us  2 h plus 4 minus 7 h minus 4 is less than or equal to 7 h minus 11 minus 7 h minus 4 .

title: Simplify
speech: Simplifying the inequality gives us  minus 5 h is less than or equal to, negative 15

title: Division Property of Inequality
text: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by $$-5$$, which gives us $$h$$ on the left hand side and $$3$$ on the right hand side.
speech: Then, we can divide both sides of the inequality by  minus, 5 , which gives us  h  on the left hand side and  3  on the right hand side.

on the left hand side and   3

title: Inequality Sign
text: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have $$h \geq 3$$.
speech: Since we divided by a negative number, the inequality reverses. Hence, we have , h is greater than or equal to 3 .

title: Interval Notation: Parentheses and Brackets
text: In interval notation, brackets are used when the left or right sides of the interval are included in the solution. For example, the expression $$"x \leq -1"$$ includes all numbers less than or equal to $$-1$$. Since $$-1$$ is included in the solution, the interval notation is $$(-\infty,-1]$$. Since $$\infty$$ represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to $$\infty$$.
speech: In interval notation, brackets are used when the left or right sides of the interval are included in the solution. For example, the expression  quotation mark x is less than or equal to negative 1 quotation mark,  includes all numbers less than or equal to  negative 1 . Since  negative 1  is included in the solution, the interval notation is , the open closed interval from negative infinity to negative 1 . Since  infinity  represents "infinity" and is not an actual number, we always put a parenthesis next to  infinity .
